Houston, we have a problem.

Hello,
I just saw that the upcoming Ariane 6 expendable launch vehicle will offer about €70M per flight price, not much higher that the flight-cost of a Falcon 9 reusable rocket. If the recovery of the first stage of a Falcon 9 saves about $60M, how does this add up? Apparently the development of Ariane 6 cost about €4B, significantly more than the $1.5B of SpaceX's Falcon 9, a fact also strange to me. Care to share your opinion on this? Thanks!

Error in description!
Does the Raptor engine really make that pulsing sound as shown in the flight animations of ITS/BFR?

I'm curious why the velocity during the final seconds of landing is always too high, and the altitude is often too low.
Even after landing, the velocity can be up to 100km/h for the next second or so.

I doubt it's a sync issue since the the onboard video is transmitted alongside the telemetry data and is subject to the same
delays.

Perhaps there are processing delays in putting the data onscreen, although that doesn't explain why the altitude is often too low.

Maybe the sample windows are too wide - while the displayed velocity values seem to be updated multiple times per second, they might be generated by interpolating data sampled at a lower rate.

Maybe it's due to granularity issues with altitude detection. At lower speeds, the change across sample intervals is small enough that aliasing becomes an issue. Doesn't really explain why the velocity is still changing when the altitude has already (prematurely) become zero - it suggests to me that the velocity is not calculated from altitude readings but from another source.

I would love to have you clear up at least one of my questions.
How can I get a better grasp of the rocket's horizontal and vertical velocity? I would love to have a better grasp of just how fast the rocket is going upwards and sideways, separately, when it releases its payload. This because I find it quite confusing how the rocket can just double back after separation with what seems like a very short burn... among other things I'd like to understand a bit better concerning the flight paths and propulsion capabilities of payloads and second stages.
I've dug around the internet, but the only thing I could find were some very technical charts and schematics, but nothing I could actually read and understand, as a layman.

Makes me wish I could have seen the Saturn V launch. That's like a small skyscraper going into orbit with about 40 MN of thrust. I think Apollo 4 didn't have a sound suppression system, which is why the rocket was shaking apart Walter Chronkite's news shack while he was broadcasting. Might have been the launch that standardized the use of sound suppression systems but I'm not sure.

On that note, wish I could see the Falcon Heavy launch in person or even the SLS.
Thx for making these videos, I'm learning a lot here and it really shows you enjoy what you're doing. Keep at it.
